htmlEmbed:
77% Of Employees Report AI Has Increased Workloads And Hampered Productivity, Study FindsBryan Robinson, Ph.D.8/28/2024

Despite 96% of C-suite executives expecting AI to boost productivity, employees say it has increased their workload, hampered productivity and caused job burnout, research shows.

AI and productivity, AI and burnout, AI and workload, CareersRead

article-body"><figure class="embed-base image-embed embed-1" role="presentation"><div style="padding-top:66.53%;position:relative" class="image-embed__placeholder"><progressive-image src="https://specials-images.forbesimg.com/imageserve/6697b02dfd565d2ce486e2df/People-using-AI-technology-for-documents-management-concept--Document-management/960x0.jpg?fit=scale" alt="People using AI technology for documents management concept, Document management concept, Businesspeople using computer to document management concept, online documentation database digital file." data-height="1590" data-width="2390"></progressive-image></div><figcaption><fbs-accordion class="expandable" current="-1"><p class="color-body light-text">Although 96% of C-suite leaders expect AI to boost worker productivity, a new study finds that 77% <span class="plus" data-ga-track="caption expand">... [+]</span><span class="expanded-caption"> of employees report AI has increased their workload.</span></p></fbs-accordion><small>getty</small></figcaption></figure>
<p>The rise in AI has caused a mixture of excitement and fear as it becomes a standard part of our lives. Some say it’s <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2023/07/07/employees-view-ai-as-an-asset-not-a-threat-according-to-new-study/" target="_self" class="color-link" title="https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2023/07/07/employees-view-ai-as-an-asset-not-a-threat-according-to-new-study/" data-ga-track="InternalLink:https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2023/07/07/employees-view-ai-as-an-asset-not-a-threat-according-to-new-study/" aria-label="a risk to civilization as we know it">a risk to civilization as we know it</a>, while others insist it will transform the way we work, live and interact with one another. The part that is not debatable is that not only is <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2024/02/12/embrace-the-fact-that-ai-will-dominate-careers-in-2024-experts-say/" target="_self" class="color-link" title="https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2024/02/12/embrace-the-fact-that-ai-will-dominate-careers-in-2024-experts-say/" data-ga-track="InternalLink:https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2024/02/12/embrace-the-fact-that-ai-will-dominate-careers-in-2024-experts-say/" aria-label="AI not going away, it’s on the upswing">AI not going away, it’s on the upswing</a>. You can get that tattooed. So it’s important to develop a reasonable comfort around its use. I realize that’s a tall order when there’s so much is written about <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2024/06/24/6-strategies-to-alleviate-employees-fears-of-ai-in-2024/" target="_self" class="color-link" title="https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2024/06/24/6-strategies-to-alleviate-employees-fears-of-ai-in-2024/" data-ga-track="InternalLink:https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2024/06/24/6-strategies-to-alleviate-employees-fears-of-ai-in-2024/" aria-label="the uncertainty of how AI will affect your job.">the uncertainty of how AI will affect your job.</a></p>
<div class="halfway_hardwall_1"></div>
<p>Several years ago, <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2019/08/23/how-artificial-intelligence-is-preventing-cognitive-overload-compassion-fatigue-and-job-burnout/" target="_self" class="color-link" title="https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2019/08/23/how-artificial-intelligence-is-preventing-cognitive-overload-compassion-fatigue-and-job-burnout/" data-ga-track="InternalLink:https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2019/08/23/how-artificial-intelligence-is-preventing-cognitive-overload-compassion-fatigue-and-job-burnout/" aria-label="I wrote a piece for Forbes.com">I wrote a piece for Forbes.com</a> titled, “How Artificial Intelligence Is Preventing Cognitive Overload, Compassion Fatigue And Job Burnout.” The article was based on speculation from various experts about the optimistic expectations of AI. But scientific findings released today contradict those expectations and re-ignite apprehensions about AI’s impact on employee overload and burnout.</p>
<div class="halfway_hardwall_2"></div>
<div class="article_paragraph_2"></div>
<h2 class="subhead-embed color-accent bg-base font-accent font-size text-align">Global Study Reveals Bad News About Employee AI Skills</h2>
<p><a href="https://www.upwork.com/hire/landing/?utm_medium=PaidSearch&utm_source=Bing&utm_campaign=SEMBrand_Bing_Domestic_Marketplace_Core&campaignid=506116836&utm_content=1274335616495213&utm_keyword=www%20upwork%20com&matchtype=p&device=c&partnerid=5106291ee9fb18bdf26e4f89158b83db&cq_plac&ad_id=79646080399393" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.upwork.com/hire/landing/?utm_medium=PaidSearch&utm_source=Bing&utm_campaign=SEMBrand_Bing_Domestic_Marketplace_Core&campaignid=506116836&utm_content=1274335616495213&utm_keyword=www%20upwork%20com&matchtype=p&device=c&partnerid=5106291ee9fb18bdf26e4f89158b83db&cq_plac&ad_id=79646080399393" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.upwork.com/hire/landing/?utm_medium=PaidSearch&utm_source=Bing&utm_campaign=SEMBrand_Bing_Domestic_Marketplace_Core&campaignid=506116836&utm_content=1274335616495213&utm_keyword=www%20upwork%20com&matchtype=p&device=c&partnerid=5106291ee9fb18bdf26e4f89158b83db&cq_plac&ad_id=79646080399393" aria-label="The new global study">The new global study</a>, in partnership with The Upwork Research Institute, interviewed 2,500 global C-suite executives, full-time employees and freelancers. Results show that the optimistic expectations about AI's impact are not aligning with the reality faced by many employees. The study identifies a disconnect between the high expectations of managers and the actual experiences of employees using AI.</p>
<div class="halfway_hardwall_3"></div>
<div class="vestpocket" vest-pocket=""></div>
<p>Despite 96% of C-suite executives expecting AI to boost productivity, the study reveals that, 77% of employees using AI say it has added to their workload and created challenges in achieving the expected productivity gains. Not only is AI increasing the workloads of full-time employees, it’s hampering productivity and contributing to employee burnout.</p>
<div class="halfway_hardwall_4"></div>
<p>To add insult to injury, nearly half (47%) of employees using AI say they don’t know how to achieve the expected productivity gains their employers expect, and 40% feel their company is asking too much of them when it comes to AI. Workers are feeling the strain from rising productivity demands, with one in three full-time employees saying they will likely quit their jobs in the next six months due to feeling overworked and burnt out. The majority of global C-suite leaders (81%) acknowledge they have increased demands on their workers in the past year. Consequently, 71% of full-time employees are burned out, and 65% report struggling with their employer’s demands on their productivity.</p>
<div class="recirc-module single-line">
			<span class="single-line-read-more">Read More: </span>
			<a class="single-line-link" data-ga-track="single-line-recirc-content_66c50c2fca535e548062fd1a" href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2024/08/26/the-new-2024-brat-trend-in-the-workplace-and-what-it-means/">The New 2024 ‘Brat’ Trend In The Workplace And What It Means</a>
		</div>
<h2 class="subhead-embed color-accent bg-base font-accent font-size text-align">Freelancers Are Saving The Workday</h2>
<p>But don’t be too quick to despair. C-suite executives, bringing in freelance talent into their workforce say freelancers are meeting productivity demands and often exceeding them, outpacing full-time employees. The level of well-being and engagement has improved. And they have doubled the following outcomes for their business: organizational agility (45%), quality of work being produced (40%), innovation (39%), scalability (39%), revenue and bottom line (36%) and efficiency (34%). The findings also show that 80% of leaders who leverage freelance talent say it is essential to their business, and 38% of leaders who don’t already leverage this talent pool intend to start in the coming year.</p>
<p>While business leaders are investing heavily in AI, the study shows that most organizations are currently failing to unlock the full productivity value of the technology. “Our research shows that introducing new technologies into outdated work models and systems is failing to unlock the full expected productivity value of AI,” says Kelly Monahan, managing director and head of The Upwork Research Institute. “While it's certainly possible for AI to simultaneously boost productivity and improve employee well-being, this outcome will require a fundamental shift in how we organize talent and work.”</p><fbs-ad position="inread" progressive="" ad-id="article-0-inread" aria-hidden="true" role="presentation"></fbs-ad>
<p>“In order to reap the full productivity value of AI, leaders need to create an AI-enhanced work model,” Monahan continues. “This includes leveraging alternative talent pools that are AI-ready, co-creating measures of productivity with their workforces, and developing a deep understanding of and proficiency in implementing a skills-based approach to hiring and talent development. Only then will leaders be able to avoid the risk of losing critical workers and advance their innovation agenda.”</p>
<h2 class="subhead-embed color-accent bg-base font-accent font-size text-align">Actions Employers And Employees Can Take</h2>
<p>Monahan argues that integrating new technologies like AI into outdated work models and systems is falling short of delivering the full productivity gains that were anticipated. She explains that to truly unlock AI's potential, leaders need a fundamental shift in how they organize talent and work. She lists four strategies for employers to consider:</p>

<p></p>
<ol>
 <li>Invest beyond the tech stack to effectively implement AI within their organizations. Our research identified three core investment opportunities that enable an AI-enhanced work model, which leads to higher workforce productivity and less burnout.</li>
 <li>Bring in outside experts to help your workforce with AI projects. We found 48% of global C-suite leaders are using freelancers to jumpstart a delayed AI project and 39% said using freelancers has doubled their innovation outcomes. AI adoption is highest amongst freelancers so don’t overlook this talent pool. Nearly half (48%) of freelancers report being "somewhat" or "highly" skilled at using AI, with over a third (34%) using AI tools at least 1 to 2 days per week.</li>
 <li>Rethink how you measure productivity.<strong> </strong>The workforce is more likely to want its productivity measured against creativity, innovation, contributions to strategy, and adaptability than efficiency-only metrics. Workers who report higher productivity and less stress are those actively involved in co-creating their productivity metrics.</li>
 <li>Start moving towards skill-based hiring and workflows rather than relying on job descriptions to organize work. Doing so requires an investment in making your workforce's existing skills visible and then developing those skills that augment AI work. Our survey found that only 40% of leaders today have a high level of awareness of the AI skills within their workforce.</li>
</ol>
<p></p>
<p>Monahan suggests that employees consider the following actions:</p>
<p></p>
<ol>
 <li>Be empowered and encouraged to engage with AI by participating in AI<strong> </strong>training programs and providing feedback on AI productivity tools and metrics to help shape effective company strategies and goals. Every worker should now think of themselves as a critical part of R&D, rethinking how to best do their work and accomplish their goals in light of AI advancements.</li>
 <li>Embrace outside expertise to come alongside you to alleviate workload concerns and teach you how to best leverage AI. Freelancers are demonstrating how AI can significantly boost productivity while enhancing well-being and engagement among employees. C-suite leaders are increasingly acknowledging that freelancers play a crucial role in driving business success. Both employers and employees should tap highly skilled freelancers to bring their specialized expertise and skill sets in AI, while fostering well-being, growth, and innovation in the workplace.</li>
</ol>
<p></p>

My books have been translated into 15 languages, and I co-host the podcast, How's That Working for Ya? The Shrink and Ms. Smarty Pants on YouTube, ITunes and Spotify. I am Professor Emeritus at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, where I conducted the first studies on children of workaholics and the effects of work addiction on marriage. I built my career on the themes of resilience and work-life balance and have lectured throughout the world on work addiction and workplace issues. My research was featured on 20/20, Good Morning America, ABC’s World News Tonight, NBC Nightly News, NBC Universal, The CBS Early Show, CNBC’s The Big Idea and NPR's Marketplace. I hosted the PBS documentary, Overdoing It: How to Slow Down and Take Care of Yourself. I maintain a private psychotherapy practice in Asheville, NC and reside in the Blue Ridge Mountains with my spouse, three dogs and occasional bears at night. class=\"color-body light-text\"\u003eAlthough 96% of C-suite leaders expect AI to boost worker productivity, a new study finds that 77% \u003cspan class=\"plus\" data-ga-track=\"caption expand\"\u003e... [+]\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"expanded-caption\"\u003e of employees report AI has increased their workload.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/fbs-accordion\u003e\u003csmall\u003egetty\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe rise in AI has caused a mixture of excitement and fear as it becomes a standard part of our lives. Some say it’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2023/07/07/employees-view-ai-as-an-asset-not-a-threat-according-to-new-study/\" target=\"_self\" class=\"color-link\" title=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2023/07/07/employees-view-ai-as-an-asset-not-a-threat-according-to-new-study/\" data-ga-track=\"InternalLink:https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2023/07/07/employees-view-ai-as-an-asset-not-a-threat-according-to-new-study/\" aria-label=\"a risk to civilization as we know it\"\u003ea risk to civilization as we know it\u003c/a\u003e, while others insist it will transform the way we work, live and interact with one another. The part that is not debatable is that not only is \u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2024/02/12/embrace-the-fact-that-ai-will-dominate-careers-in-2024-experts-say/\" target=\"_self\" class=\"color-link\" title=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2024/02/12/embrace-the-fact-that-ai-will-dominate-careers-in-2024-experts-say/\" data-ga-track=\"InternalLink:https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2024/02/12/embrace-the-fact-that-ai-will-dominate-careers-in-2024-experts-say/\" aria-label=\"AI not going away, it’s on the upswing\"\u003eAI not going away, it’s on the upswing\u003c/a\u003e. You can get that tattooed. So it’s important to develop a reasonable comfort around its use. I realize that’s a tall order when there’s so much is written about \u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2024/06/24/6-strategies-to-alleviate-employees-fears-of-ai-in-2024/\" target=\"_self\" class=\"color-link\" title=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2024/06/24/6-strategies-to-alleviate-employees-fears-of-ai-in-2024/\" data-ga-track=\"InternalLink:https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2024/06/24/6-strategies-to-alleviate-employees-fears-of-ai-in-2024/\" aria-label=\"the uncertainty of how AI will affect your job.\"\u003ethe uncertainty of how AI will affect your job.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"halfway_hardwall_1\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeveral years ago, \u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2019/08/23/how-artificial-intelligence-is-preventing-cognitive-overload-compassion-fatigue-and-job-burnout/\" target=\"_self\" class=\"color-link\" title=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2019/08/23/how-artificial-intelligence-is-preventing-cognitive-overload-compassion-fatigue-and-job-burnout/\" data-ga-track=\"InternalLink:https://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2019/08/23/how-artificial-intelligence-is-preventing-cognitive-overload-compassion-fatigue-and-job-burnout/\" aria-label=\"I wrote a piece for Forbes.com\"\u003eI wrote a piece for Forbes.com\u003c/a\u003e titled, “How Artificial Intelligence Is Preventing Cognitive Overload, Compassion Fatigue And Job Burnout.” The article was based on speculation from various experts about the optimistic expectations of AI. But scientific findings released today contradict those expectations and re-ignite apprehensions about AI’s impact on employee overload and burnout.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"halfway_hardwall_2\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"article_paragraph_2\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch2 class=\"subhead-embed color-accent bg-base font-accent font-size text-align\"\u003eGlobal Study Reveals Bad News About Employee AI Skills\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.upwork.com/hire/landing/?utm_medium=PaidSearch\u0026amp;utm_source=Bing\u0026amp;utm_campaign=SEMBrand_Bing_Domestic_Marketplace_Core\u0026amp;campaignid=506116836\u0026amp;utm_content=1274335616495213\u0026amp;utm_keyword=www%20upwork%20com\u0026amp;matchtype=p\u0026amp;device=c\u0026amp;partnerid=5106291ee9fb18bdf26e4f89158b83db\u0026amp;cq_plac\u0026amp;ad_id=79646080399393\" rel=\"nofollow noopener noreferrer\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"color-link\" title=\"https://www.upwork.com/hire/landing/?utm_medium=PaidSearch\u0026amp;utm_source=Bing\u0026amp;utm_campaign=SEMBrand_Bing_Domestic_Marketplace_Core\u0026amp;campaignid=506116836\u0026amp;utm_content=1274335616495213\u0026amp;utm_keyword=www%20upwork%20com\u0026amp;matchtype=p\u0026amp;device=c\u0026amp;partnerid=5106291ee9fb18bdf26e4f89158b83db\u0026amp;cq_plac\u0026amp;ad_id=79646080399393\" data-ga-track=\"ExternalLink:https://www.upwork.com/hire/landing/?utm_medium=PaidSearch\u0026amp;utm_source=Bing\u0026amp;utm_campaign=SEMBrand_Bing_Domestic_Marketplace_Core\u0026amp;campaignid=506116836\u0026amp;utm_content=1274335616495213\u0026amp;utm_keyword=www%20upwork%20com\u0026amp;matchtype=p\u0026amp;device=c\u0026amp;partnerid=5106291ee9fb18bdf26e4f89158b83db\u0026amp;cq_plac\u0026amp;ad_id=79646080399393\" aria-label=\"The new global study\"\u003eThe new global study\u003c/a\u003e, in partnership with The Upwork Research Institute, interviewed 2,500 global C-suite executives, full-time employees and freelancers. Results show that the optimistic expectations about AI's impact are not aligning with the reality faced by many employees. The study identifies a disconnect between the high expectations of managers and the actual experiences of employees using AI.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"halfway_hardwall_3\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"vestpocket\" vest-pocket=\"\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite 96% of C-suite executives expecting AI to boost productivity, the study reveals that, 77% of employees using AI say it has added to their workload and created challenges in achieving the expected productivity gains. Not only is AI increasing the workloads of full-time employees, it’s hampering productivity and contributing to employee burnout.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"halfway_hardwall_4\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo add insult to injury, nearly half (47%) of employees using AI say they don’t know how to achieve the expected productivity gains their employers expect, and 40% feel their company is asking too much of them when it comes to AI. Workers are feeling the strain from rising productivity demands, with one in three full-time employees saying they will likely quit their jobs in the next six months due to feeling overworked and burnt out. The majority of global C-suite leaders (81%) acknowledge they have increased demands on their workers in the past year. Consequently, 71% of full-time employees are burned out, and 65% report struggling with their employer’s demands on their productivity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"recirc-module single-line\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\u003cspan class=\"single-line-read-more\"\u003eRead More: \u003c/span\u003e\n\t\t\t\u003ca class=\"single-line-link\" data-ga-track=\"single-line-recirc-content_66c50c2fca535e548062fd1a\" href=\"http://www.forbes.com/sites/bryanrobinson/2024/08/26/the-new-2024-brat-trend-in-the-workplace-and-what-it-means/\"\u003eThe New 2024 ‘Brat’ Trend In The Workplace And What It Means\u003c/a\u003e\n\t\t\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch2 class=\"subhead-embed color-accent bg-base font-accent font-size text-align\"\u003eFreelancers Are Saving The Workday\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut don’t be too quick to despair. C-suite executives, bringing in freelance talent into their workforce say freelancers are meeting productivity demands and often exceeding them, outpacing full-time employees. The level of well-being and engagement has improved. And they have doubled the following outcomes for their business: organizational agility (45%), quality of work being produced (40%), innovation (39%), scalability (39%), revenue and bottom line (36%) and efficiency (34%). The findings also show that 80% of leaders who leverage freelance talent say it is essential to their business, and 38% of leaders who don’t already leverage this talent pool intend to start in the coming year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile business leaders are investing heavily in AI, the study shows that most organizations are currently failing to unlock the full productivity value of the technology. “Our research shows that introducing new technologies into outdated work models and systems is failing to unlock the full expected productivity value of AI,” says Kelly Monahan, managing director and head of The Upwork Research Institute. “While it's certainly possible for AI to simultaneously boost productivity and improve employee well-being, this outcome will require a fundamental shift in how we organize talent and work.”\u003c/p\u003e\u003cfbs-ad position=\"inread\" progressive=\"\" ad-id=\"article-0-inread\" aria-hidden=\"true\" role=\"presentation\"\u003e\u003c/fbs-ad\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“In order to reap the full productivity value of AI, leaders need to create an AI-enhanced work model,” Monahan continues. “This includes leveraging alternative talent pools that are AI-ready, co-creating measures of productivity with their workforces, and developing a deep understanding of and proficiency in implementing a skills-based approach to hiring and talent development. Only then will leaders be able to avoid the risk of losing critical workers and advance their innovation agenda.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 class=\"subhead-embed color-accent bg-base font-accent font-size text-align\"\u003eActions Employers And Employees Can Take\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMonahan argues that integrating new technologies like AI into outdated work models and systems is falling short of delivering the full productivity gains that were anticipated. She explains that to truly unlock AI's potential, leaders need a fundamental shift in how they organize talent and work. })();\n\u003c/script\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n \u003cli\u003eInvest beyond the tech stack to effectively implement AI within their organizations. Our research identified three core investment opportunities that enable an AI-enhanced work model, which leads to higher workforce productivity and less burnout.\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003eBring in outside experts to help your workforce with AI projects. We found 48% of global C-suite leaders are using freelancers to jumpstart a delayed AI project and 39% said using freelancers has doubled their innovation outcomes. AI adoption is highest amongst freelancers so don’t overlook this talent pool. Nearly half (48%) of freelancers report being \"somewhat\" or \"highly\" skilled at using AI, with over a third (34%) using AI tools at least 1 to 2 days per week.\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003eRethink how you measure productivity.\u003cstrong\u003e \u003c/strong\u003eThe workforce is more likely to want its productivity measured against creativity, innovation, contributions to strategy, and adaptability than efficiency-only metrics. Workers who report higher productivity and less stress are those actively involved in co-creating their productivity metrics.\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003eStart moving towards skill-based hiring and workflows rather than relying on job descriptions to organize work. Doing so requires an investment in making your workforce's existing skills visible and then developing those skills that augment AI work. Our survey found that only 40% of leaders today have a high level of awareness of the AI skills within their workforce.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMonahan suggests that employees consider the following actions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n \u003cli\u003eBe empowered and encouraged to engage with AI by participating in AI\u003cstrong\u003e \u003c/strong\u003etraining programs and providing feedback on AI productivity tools and metrics to help shape effective company strategies and goals. Every worker should now think of themselves as a critical part of R\u0026amp;D, rethinking how to best do their work and accomplish their goals in light of AI advancements.\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003eEmbrace outside expertise to come alongside you to alleviate workload concerns and teach you how to best leverage AI. Freelancers are demonstrating how AI can significantly boost productivity while enhancing well-being and engagement among employees. C-suite leaders are increasingly acknowledging that freelancers play a crucial role in driving business success. Both employers and employees should tap highly skilled freelancers to bring their specialized expertise and skill sets in AI, while fostering well-being, growth, and innovation in the workplace.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"article_paragraph_7\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv readabilityObject.title: 77% Of Employees Report AI Has Increased Workloads And Hampered Productivity, Study Finds
readabilityObject.content:
The rise in AI has caused a mixture of excitement and fear as it becomes a standard part of our lives. Some say it’s a risk to civilization as we know it, while others insist it will transform the way we work, live and interact with one another. The part that is not debatable is that not only is AI not going away, it’s on the upswing. You can get that tattooed. So it’s important to develop a reasonable comfort around its use. I realize that’s a tall order when there’s so much is written about the uncertainty of how AI will affect your job.

Several years ago, I wrote a piece for Forbes.com titled, “How Artificial Intelligence Is Preventing Cognitive Overload, Compassion Fatigue And Job Burnout.” The article was based on speculation from various experts about the optimistic expectations of AI. But scientific findings released today contradict those expectations and re-ignite apprehensions about AI’s impact on employee overload and burnout.

Global Study Reveals Bad News About Employee AI Skills

The new global study, in partnership with The Upwork Research Institute, interviewed 2,500 global C-suite executives, full-time employees and freelancers. Results show that the optimistic expectations about AI's impact are not aligning with the reality faced by many employees. The study identifies a disconnect between the high expectations of managers and the actual experiences of employees using AI.

Despite 96% of C-suite executives expecting AI to boost productivity, the study reveals that, 77% of employees using AI say it has added to their workload and created challenges in achieving the expected productivity gains. Not only is AI increasing the workloads of full-time employees, it’s hampering productivity and contributing to employee burnout.

To add insult to injury, nearly half (47%) of employees using AI say they don’t know how to achieve the expected productivity gains their employers expect, and 40% feel their company is asking too much of them when it comes to AI. Workers are feeling the strain from rising productivity demands, with one in three full-time employees saying they will likely quit their jobs in the next six months due to feeling overworked and burnt out. The majority of global C-suite leaders (81%) acknowledge they have increased demands on their workers in the past year. Consequently, 71% of full-time employees are burned out, and 65% report struggling with their employer’s demands on their productivity.

Freelancers Are Saving The Workday

But don’t be too quick to despair. C-suite executives, bringing in freelance talent into their workforce say freelancers are meeting productivity demands and often exceeding them, outpacing full-time employees. The level of well-being and engagement has improved. And they have doubled the following outcomes for their business: organizational agility (45%), quality of work being produced (40%), innovation (39%), scalability (39%), revenue and bottom line (36%) and efficiency (34%). The findings also show that 80% of leaders who leverage freelance talent say it is essential to their business, and 38% of leaders who don’t already leverage this talent pool intend to start in the coming year.

While business leaders are investing heavily in AI, the study shows that most organizations are currently failing to unlock the full productivity value of the technology. “Our research shows that introducing new technologies into outdated work models and systems is failing to unlock the full expected productivity value of AI,” says Kelly Monahan, managing director and head of The Upwork Research Institute. “While it's certainly possible for AI to simultaneously boost productivity and improve employee well-being, this outcome will require a fundamental shift in how we organize talent and work.”

“In order to reap the full productivity value of AI, leaders need to create an AI-enhanced work model,” Monahan continues. “This includes leveraging alternative talent pools that are AI-ready, co-creating measures of productivity with their workforces, and developing a deep understanding of and proficiency in implementing a skills-based approach to hiring and talent development. Only then will leaders be able to avoid the risk of losing critical workers and advance their innovation agenda.”

Actions Employers And Employees Can Take

Monahan argues that integrating new technologies like AI into outdated work models and systems is falling short of delivering the full productivity gains that were anticipated. She explains that to truly unlock AI's potential, leaders need a fundamental shift in how they organize talent and work. She lists four strategies for employers to consider:

  1. Invest beyond the tech stack to effectively implement AI within their organizations. Our research identified three core investment opportunities that enable an AI-enhanced work model, which leads to higher workforce productivity and less burnout.
  2. Bring in outside experts to help your workforce with AI projects. We found 48% of global C-suite leaders are using freelancers to jumpstart a delayed AI project and 39% said using freelancers has doubled their innovation outcomes. AI adoption is highest amongst freelancers so don’t overlook this talent pool. Nearly half (48%) of freelancers report being "somewhat" or "highly" skilled at using AI, with over a third (34%) using AI tools at least 1 to 2 days per week.
  3. Rethink how you measure productivity. The workforce is more likely to want its productivity measured against creativity, innovation, contributions to strategy, and adaptability than efficiency-only metrics. Workers who report higher productivity and less stress are those actively involved in co-creating their productivity metrics.
  4. Start moving towards skill-based hiring and workflows rather than relying on job descriptions to organize work. Doing so requires an investment in making your workforce's existing skills visible and then developing those skills that augment AI work. Our survey found that only 40% of leaders today have a high level of awareness of the AI skills within their workforce.

Monahan suggests that employees consider the following actions:

  1. Be empowered and encouraged to engage with AI by participating in AI training programs and providing feedback on AI productivity tools and metrics to help shape effective company strategies and goals. Every worker should now think of themselves as a critical part of R&D, rethinking how to best do their work and accomplish their goals in light of AI advancements.
  2. Embrace outside expertise to come alongside you to alleviate workload concerns and teach you how to best leverage AI. Freelancers are demonstrating how AI can significantly boost productivity while enhancing well-being and engagement among employees. C-suite leaders are increasingly acknowledging that freelancers play a crucial role in driving business success. Both employers and employees should tap highly skilled freelancers to bring their specialized expertise and skill sets in AI, while fostering well-being, growth, and innovation in the workplace.
